data.title: Fixed: Markdown syntax highlighting to support alternative header styles
data.body:
Fixes #9784.

The paragraph TM rule was excluding heading-setext alt heading 2 rule, because of a conflict with the separator rule.

Also added tests to verify the behaviour.

data.title: "Go to definition" command show wrong file.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.2
- C/C++: 0.8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Select header file of some class in workspace file browser.
2. Go to definition of some its methods.
3. Cpp file is opened but its path isn't relative to root of the workspace. In "Open Editors" section it is displayed as path from root of the drive (cut on left side: "t/subfolder/file.cpp") with hint  "/Users/admin/project/subfolder/file.cpp". The hint of tab shows "/Users/admin/project/subfolder/file.cpp"
4. Breakpoints can not be set if file was opened in above described way.
5. Two instances of the same file can be shown in tabs.

data.title: Broken syntax highlighting in for loops in JavaScript
Snippet completion of repeated tokens fails when first token autocompletes with a preceding character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Windows 10

Completing a snippet, where the `$1` token occurs more than once and where the first instance of the token is preceded by a character that triggers autocompletion in the editor, causes subsequent completions of the `$1` token to overwrite the preceding character with the preceding characters from the autocompletion.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/298883/18032075/edcc1a8e-6d3d-11e6-8205-79859bf17360.png)

![vscode-snippet-completion-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/298883/18032063/7f365300-6d3d-11e6-9e03-228ccff321cc.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Use the following snippet (or any snippet containing two or more instances of the `$1` token where the first token is preceded by an underscore:

``` json
{
    "prefix": "t1",
    "body": [
        "this._$1 = void 0;",
        "this.get('$1');"
    ]
}
```
1. Create a new file with the same language as the snippet. Enter the following into the editor:

``` js
this._foo = 1;
```
1. Use the snippet by typing `t1` into the editor on a subsequent line and pressing tab
2. Type `_foo` for the snippet completion and then press TAB to complete the snippet (which will also unwittingly trigger autocompletion)
3. The apostrophe preceding the second token is overwritten using the underscore from the autocompletion selection

**Workaround**

Pressing escape to cancel autocompletion before pressing tab to complete the snippet will stop autocompletion from ruining the snippet result.

data.title: [PHP] Syntax highlighting broken by part of my code.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider (had this issue in older builds as well) - OS Version: Windows 10 64bit (Anniversary Update) **I tried with different color themes as well. Same issue.** First of all, I know that having such long php files is not a good thing. BUT the syntax highlighting breaks in my php file after a certain section (which has a lot of quotation marks and apostrophes). My file is 389 lines but it breaks at line 303. I don't want to copy-paste the whole code, but I can copy the section which seems to break my syntax highlighting. ``` php
``` Copying this section in itself doesn't break syntax highlighting, but if I take this part out, the syntax starts working again. I tried to add extra code to stretch the file out to 390+ lines again after taking out this part of the code and it still worked. I didn't find any issues like this (tried with and without extensions as well). Here is where it breaks: ![issue1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6963476/18030617/e2b03152-6cbc-11e6-82a3-24453ced78ad.jpg) I take out the "bad" part: ![issue2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6963476/18030618/e2b20982-6cbc-11e6-9c6a-6b37c11da0d6.jpg) I add the "bad" part at the end of the file and yet it breaks the syntax highlight again: ![issue3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6963476/18030620/e2b67166-6cbc-11e6-949b-e33e3c84db1a.jpg) I completely take out the "bad" part (end of my file): ![issue4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6963476/18030619/e2b591ec-6cbc-11e6-9974-99cc2fbab7e0.jpg) Leaving the "bad" code where it was, this is the end of my file (file in original state): ![issue5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6963476/18030629/26a2463e-6cbd-11e6-85b4-6f82d7f18945.jpg)

``` json
        "contentIconPath": "http://image.flaticon.com/icons/svg/188/188918.svg",
        "height": "14px",
        "width": "14px"
    }
}
```

2) Set the decoration and notice the gutter icon appears, but the inline icon is missing

data.title: Cannot copy/paste from Ubuntu VSCode into virtual machine guests
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Get a Ubuntu 16.04 PC
2. Install VSCode
3. Setup two VMware Player (v12.1.1 build-3770994) machines
   - OSX 10.11
   - Windows 10
   - install VMware Tools in both
4. Open a guest
5. Copy something from the editor of the Ubuntu VSCode
6. Try to paste it anywhere in the guest (won't work)
7. Go back to host
8. Paste the text somewhere (will work, i.e. the text is in the clipboard)
9. Copy that SAME text from wherever you pasted it in the host
10. Paste it anywhere in the guest (will work this time, oddly)

Steps 9-11 show the simple workaround: Copy the text from VSCode, paste in a text editor, copy that, paste in the guest machine.

A very minor but odd issue.

Probably worth listing my VSCode extensions:
- Visual Studio Code Settings Sync 2.0.6
- Python 0.3.21
- C/C++ 0.8.1
- C# 1.3.0
- vscode-icons 1.8.1

data.title: Disambiguation when two or more snippets conflict
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Since two or more extensions can use the same `prefix` to register different snippets, it would be nice if Visual Studio Code could show which extension the snippet belongs to.

I created the gif below showing how the disambiguation could work - a label placed on the right side showing which extensions is responsible for that snippet.

![snippets](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19753339/18026826/ac9948a2-6c52-11e6-8b20-0b216ed34cdc.gif)

Thank you.

data.title: Text cursor stops blinking in integrated terminal if you run external command
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0, 1.5.0-insider 2016-08-26T08:02:25.854Z
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

**Steps to Reproduce:**

user setting: `"terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking": true`
1. Open integrated terminal - the text cursor is blinking :white_check_mark:
2. Run `less file.txt` or `man awk` or `mc`
3. Quit the external command ("q" or F10)

**Expected result**
- the text cursor is blinking

**Actual result**
- the text cursor is not blinking

**Workaround**
- restart the terminal window

data.body:
- VSCode Version:

1.4

debian 8

Steps to Reproduce:

For many times, I didn't intend to drag and move a folder, but for whatever reason, maybe my mouse is too sensitive, a folder was moved. The moving process is so fast that I didn't notice it.
Some time later, I found the folder was missing. Ok, you know how confusing I am. ...

data.title: Run Custom Commands (filter)
data.body:
There already a couple of extensions available doing a very similar thing, running a custom command. I am not talking about something like the Task runner which is already part of vscode, but of extensions like these:
- [vscode-filtertext](https://github.com/yhirose/vscode-filtertext)
- [vscode-shell](https://github.com/bbenoist/vscode-shell)
- [LaunchTerminal](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=testingtestingtesting.launchterminal)
- [OpenVim](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mattn.OpenVim)
- [Run on Save](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=emeraldwalk.RunOnSave)
- ...

My proposal is to add these features to the vscode so people don't have to rely on extensions for these things. I am thinking about a _more generic version_ which lets you:
- Execute a custom commands
- Execute a custom commands in the integrated terminal
- Pre-configure commands in the user's config
- Bind custom keyboard shortcuts to (pre-configured) commands
- Have variables available which get replaced with things like the current filepath, filename, working directory, line number, preferred line length (for [`par`](http://vimcasts.org/episodes/formatting-text-with-par/))
- Pass selected text to command
- Filter selected text with command (like `sort -r`)
- Read in output of a command

Maybe even:
- Attach triggers like _onSave_ to a command

Let me know what you think about integrating this directly into vscode. Keep in mind that vi's `:!` covers  a lot of these cases and has been a feature right from the start.

data.title: Task builder icon keeps turning
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Build a typescript project

Expected outcome: once the compilation has finished, the running icon should stop.

Actual outcome: this doesn't always happen. In particular, only the first build stops the icon from running, it seems.

Settings:

tsconfig.json:

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "commonjs",
        "noImplicitAny": true,
        "removeComments": true,
        "preserveConstEnums": true,
        "sourceMap": true,
        "target": "es6"
    },
    "files": [ bunch of .ts files ]
}
```

Any suggestions welcome.

data.title: [bash] syntax coloring should accept options on shebang line
data.body:
A bash script may have its first line

``` bash
#!/bin/bash -eu
```

to modify the behavior of the bash session.

The Visual Studio Code syntax colorizer cannot handle this as of version 0.1.0
to fix add a “.*” after bash:

``` bash
diff package.json /usr/share/code/resources/app/extensions/shellscript/package.json
12c12
<                       "firstLine": "^#!.*\\b(bash|zsh|sh|tcsh)|^#\\s*-\\*-[^*]*mode:\\s*shell-script[^*]*-\\*-",

---
>                       "firstLine": "^#!.*\\b(bash|zsh|sh|tcsh).*|^#\\s*-\\*-[^*]*mode:\\s*shell-script[^*]*-\\*-",
```

To verify fix
1. Open a file with first line `#!/bin/bash -eu`
2. Verify in status bar on lower right that colorizer is Shell Script (Bash)

> dpkg --status code | egrep "^(V|Pa)" && lsb_release --description --codename
> Package: code
> Version: 1.4.0-1470329130
> Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS
> Codename:       xenial

data.title: VSCode Git doesn't see files moved into subdirectory
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update
- Git Version: `git version 2.8.1.windows.1`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone a Git repository (https://github.com/SocketCluster/sc-sample-inventory)
2. Move everyting from root folder into subfolder
3. VSCode doesn't show / commit changes

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/466713/18023772/8d3fc99c-6bba-11e6-9347-fc4985d093c9.png)

This resulted in me "losing" tons of files in my project. I had to go to the Git command line to "see" the modified files and commit them. @joaomoreno @bpasero 

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: Avoid multiple updates when file search is cached
data.body:
@bpasero this is a possible fix for the flickering of QuickOpen. It seems to be a noticeable improvement, but I'm not sure what you had in mind as a long term fix.

As I'm heading out soon, I don't want to push this without your approval. Please feel free to ignore or merge.

data.title: Searching within files causes windows defender (antimalware.exe) to run and takes over my computer for 30 minutes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Bring up search (Ctrl + Shift + F)
2. Search
3. Antimalware.exe process starts and computer cpu goes to 100%. Search never completes and progress indicator stops updating at 90%.
